reviewText:
Time has slowed down to the point of almost standing completely still, or rather: movement has. The world has lost its force, in the physical sense of the word, and it has halted any progression save for the player, and a rather major antagonist. This is where TIMEframe sets off.

There is this direct punch to the game that is very powerful. It hits the right notes with its initial choice of music and spawn-point. Before you there is a giant sun glaring at you, signifying cleverly the player's path forward. This in tandem with the music that is constituted by this bright powerful guitar strums and finger-picking with some nice alternative tunings (I assume). And once you step out of the edifice you spawned in, it becomes overwhelmingly beautiful. Direct comparisons would lead to Journey, only without the fluidity and particle effects, which makes sense due to the time-flux problematic we have at hand. But aesthetically there is this similar orange hew filling the screen, but in a darker, more abrasive way. It is not as soft as Journey, and following the lines of this jaggedness, there are bare polygons, but they themselves create a mosaic image of different shades of dust and desert. It is not as soft, but still beautiful enough to warrant a response of some kind. Slightly reminiscent of something like Shelter, although a bit more subtle.

Following the Journey comparison, there is also a vastness of space, seemingly unimportant considering time is stood still, but for the player the vast is still vast. Journey combated this with an incredible movement system, with sand being sweetly pushed aside by the fluidity of your garment. In TIMEframe we have a slightly less satisfying way to move forward, making the vast feel like a hindrance, instead of a joyous sign of there being a lot to explore. Even with the slight drudgery that accompanies moving through the spatial, the atmosphere makes up for it. You start feeling like you're not that far away, and there are always things to look at that distract you from the menial process of getting there. The sky seems like a dome of fire that, even though static, feels vibrant.

TIMEframe gives you a time-frame within which you are supposed to explore. The idea is to explore. The game gives you a lot more to explore than mere buildings or statues. It accompanies each finding with a text, each one filling the game with more and more – not only content, that I imagine you're interested in – but with a sort of depth. Ruins do not merely mean tourist attraction, or “exploration”, as the game had written it is much more: “Memories lost to death streams can sometimes be revealed through stone”. It is rare I feel a strong need to quote a game. Or a game that with its mechanics and aesthetic, with its concept, signify an idea much greater than its medium. Everything is connected in TIMEframe, you are playing through a thought out game, a concept realized.

For what TIMEframe sets out to do is fantastic. Its selected writings and setting symbolizes something very special. Something I've had trouble with articulating succinctly. Annihilation is inevitable, impermanence is a fact, and before its imminent strike, there are things to explore, a world to live through and with, and a past world all the same. This game reads like a love-letter to the history of ideas and lost civilizations that with a direct causal link built ours. There are multiple philosophical ideas, mostly existential, that are tackled in this game, all that are bound to at least evoke some type of reaction in the player. Attempts have been made to create a philosophically inscribed game, but it has often failed due to either being far too pretentious or far too insecure in its elucidation of the concepts themselves, either through text or aesthetics – or mechanics! TIMEframe hits a balance, despite not being the most graphically advanced or aesthetically out there, it follows a theme and it does it very well.

I expected a minimalist exploration game, but I found something almost incredible. This is a game that actually deals with the looming threat of death. It deals with surrendering, with acquiescence, with the rationalist defeat against the overwhelming cruelty of nature. Mind does not defeat matter. Memory and mind, dies with the death of the stream, mind and memory dies with you. The they-self, as Heidegger put it, and the equivalence of Flesh, as Francis Bacon put it, both realize, along with this game, the sadness and destructive force of the world. Stones lives on, memories do not. Artifacts are preserved, humans wither away, humans become dust. And that dust is you. The message is strong enough for revivalists to abandon their practice.

It's an effective game. The musical cues are on point, soft acoustic goes into orchestral at the right moments, and uses ambient atmospheric music equally as effectively. This adds to making new places and new texts more digestible, more evocative. Musically, the game has a backbone, something that props up everything and elevates it to what it is, as compared to what it otherwise could have been without its context: unimportant, ambiguous or pointless. It is manipulative, sure, but not without merit, not without substituting the being manipulated part with being given actual substance. Nothing is unimportant, nor pointless, albeit slightly ambiguous, but in a mysterious way that stimulates the mind to associate and grasp the abstract and drag it down to the concrete.

In a way this is an anti-game. It slows down time, it removes the ADHD-like propensity towards fast action and movement, it slows the player down as well, and it gives room to think and reflect. At the same time, however, there is an immense agency to the game, a nagging stress, much akin to the one we feel in real life before death, that begs the player to accomplish, to accomplish and accomplish, before his or her doom. Will you have time to do everything you want to do in life? If the game is the ruler: no. But within the theme of the game things remain, topological and intellectual traces exist and carry on. Here I part ways with the game philosophically, but it does not mean I do not appreciate what it attempts to confer upon the rest of us.

A part of me feels that TIMEframe is open enough for people, both in the way they play and think, to create their own meaning. In minor ways, perhaps, as the general themes are glaringly obvious, but still with a great deal of satisfaction.

I would wholeheartedly recommend TIMEframe. It is humbling, as you weep before your great annihilation, that you are painfully aware of, to be faced with ideas like this, in a medium like this: it makes me happy. It is a good experience, with wonderful expression of concepts and with an intriguing story to boot. Not everything is clear, but it becomes clear as you envelope yourself in this world. You will not regret trying it, buying it; at least I didn't.

reviewText: I have sat by and watched the games media criticize games like gone home" and "dear esther" for not being games. This has always really bugged me. I for one loved those games and thoroughly enjoyed playing them. But I now understand what games critics say when they call something "not a game". TIMEframe is an "experience"
date: not a game. To me what makes the prior ones games and not this one is the fact that you actually feel like you are achieving something
recommended:
even if in reality you aren't.

In the likes of gone home you do similar to TIMEframe were you just walk about and collect items that give you information. The difference with gone home is that these items give you a sense of a story. So when collecting these items you are doing it for a reason and are discovering new things in the process. But in TIMEframe the locations you have to discover give you only a short note. The notes don't have much relation to each other and aren't interesting to read. I didn't feel any anticipation for what would lie at the next location.

So the steam description mentions that the world is in slow motion. How exactly does this affect my gameplay? The answer is that it doesn't. This is what I found most intriguing when looking into this game. But it has basically no input in the game aside from making it look good. Some items in the world that would usually be moving instead are moving in extremely slow motion. I have to admit they did look nice in this style but I was hoping slow motion would be a mechanic in the game that I would be able to use to my advantage.

But what is the goal of the game? There are 14 different iconic locations scattered around the map. Your goal is to go to each of the locations. When you reach each of the locations you get a short extract to read. This seems simple enough right? The problem is the game seems to try to hinder your process every 10 minutes. There is a meteor that is coming down on the world in slow motion. After 10 minutes it hits
hoursPlayed:
the screen goes white and you are teleported back to the beginning to go and explore again. I personally would have preferred it if I had the option to teleport back to the start whenever I wanted instead of having it forcably put upon me all the time.

reviewText:
Timeframe a beautiful yet basic game. The game is a short experience, and a pretty one at that. If you like those type of walking simulators, then this will be a treat for you.

The entire game plays in one big open area. A civilization on the brink of being smashed to pieces by a giant meteor. you have 10 seconds to explore the world. Luckily those 10 seconds have been slowed down to 10 minutes. Everything in the world goes in slow motion except you the player. It's beautiful to see the water flowing slowly from a dam or fountain, flags waving very slow in the city or leaves falling from a tree.

The goal of the game is to explorer 14 locations in the world. each of these locations will give you some scripture about the history of the place you are in and what is happening. Other then your map that give some indication on where each location is, it is up to you to explorer them all. Each time the meteor hits, the screen will turn white and puts you back at the beginning. But it saves the progress of each explored location. Once you visited all locations a new location will pop up on your map for the ending.

Think overall while the game is pretty short, it does capture a beautiful place and story. This is being brought together by a beautiful soundtrack that really gets you in the moment. I personally thought it was well worth the 8 bucks they asked for it, if your on the fence, i would wait for a sale, otherwise i would suggest you pick it up.

reviewText:
TIMEframe is an exploration game set in the end of the world. You have 10 seconds to explore the open area in slow motion, meaning you got about 10 minutes before the earth gets struck by a cataclysm from outer space. After that, you can repeat and explore again.

PROS:
+ Nice atmosphere
+ Relaxing music
+ Both high and low quality textures have their own beauties
+ Trading cards

CONS:
- Gets repetitive almost right off the bat: literally all you do is hold the walk key and occasionally clicking an item to inspect its description
- Very short gameplay; can be finished within an hour
- Very little content for its already reasonably low price

I don't find this game bad, but there's really not much in it and I barely consider it ''a game'' for the lack of options you have. If you're in for a short trip through a hillside area with ancient structures to discover, pick it up, preferably at a low price, as with the current price/content ratio, I cannot recommend it.

My rating: 6.5/10

It's not so common.  Not at all.  I've walked in on the last 10 seconds before oblivion.  Walked through their fields of flowers, wandered into their abandoned city and stood in surprise of the beauty that is fated to die.  Just before a civilization disappears those moments are stretched out longer for me to seek the meanings and understand the hearts of those who are about to pass away.  TIMEframe is an epitaph of a world, yet more than that.  It shares with me the gentle strength of a brave civilization coming to terms with death on their horizon.

If you are fond of reading plaques about the history of a location, or find yourself more apt to explore a game world than play in it , this game may suit you well.  Gameplay consists of you walking, exploring, and discovering inscribed objects  that reward you with excerpts from the past of  their culture.  Some are of religions explaining the coming apocolypse.  Others are of wisdom, factual explanations,  or comforting poems.  Most all of them show a culture that knows an immenent disaster is about to end all that they have.  What comes through all these searches for the backstory is an honest account of how these people felt as they came to acknowledge and accept their fate.

There are no puzzles, no fights, no solving, no true storyline or anything. You walk, enjoy the world around you and learn about them all within a short amount of time before the Nomad" meteor crashes and destroys them all in a white flash. Then you repeat the process until you have completed a map that guides you to those epitaphs.  There is an ending as well. Personally
date: I think anything else would not reflect the mood of the game.  And it strikes a chord.  Maybe it's because I've seen loved ones gather this same calmness before they pass. reviewText:
Imagine you appear in a world where there are 12 different wonders of a civilization that has been destroyed, or perhaps they have vanished. Now imagine that there is a comet, or perhaps it is simply a prophetic encounter that seems to have occurred, and that you will experience this event as well.

In TIMEframe, you are not going to be running around, talking to people, you are going to be take a soft music journey to uncover what was hidden about these 12 wonders, and perhaps unlock the power of an object left in this world. There is one catch, however, and that is that you shall find yourself constantly returning to the spire, which is where your story begins, but have no fear, the actions that you take in those 10 minute increments will be retained.

One of the ways that you will know that time is almost up is hidden in the music, now you might not catch it the first couple of times but it will be the harbinger of your position in the world resetting. In so regards this can be a good thing, mainly because it is possible to get lost in the world, and to restart back in a centralized point, can get you back on the correct path that you need to be on.

You will find that by pressing the Spacebar you will reveal many dots on the screen laid out in an infinity pattern. You'll also notice that if you successfully reach one of the wonders in this world that that dot will change into a symbol. If you unlock all the symbols you will be able to progress the game into the ending.

I'm going to be totally honest with you, when I first heard about this game I was told it was in the same vein as Dear Ester, and in a way it is, but it also isn't. Dear Ester seemed more like a guided tour, this game at times seems like a blind journey. Now that's not saying that this game is lacking something, but it does take a little bit of time to get used to, and it also takes patience, ESPECIALLY since you might find yourself within a stone's throw of a wonder, and the special music is playing, and you know that you're not going to make it before the world resets again.

That can be frustrating, and to add to matters you are going to be walking the entire time, there is no run or speed walk button, you are going to be taking in the sights, you are going to be walking through this little window in time, and although at first I didn't know if I was going to be able to hang with this game, I've got to admit that once I accepted the reset, and the natural pace, I got hooked into wanting to see what would happen when I visited all the wonders.

This is definitely not a game for everyone, but this is a kind of meditative game that one can definitely lose time in. I do kind of wish that when you interacted with the wonders, and you got that small quote or bit of history that it was spoken in some kind of interesting accent, but at the same time I don't know if that would actually end up hurting the experience, either way this is something that in the end I enjoyed, and to be honest part of me was a little same to see the credits roll, of course there was a part of me as well that felt a great deal of accomplishment after finally seeing this game all the way through. So in the end I think I'm going to have to give this game an 8.2 out of 10.

reviewText:
TIMEframe – A short story on Art vs. Games.

There are games in this world that border on art, and this would be one of them.
This game is equal parts Journey (art direction)if it was first person, The soundtrack of a triple A title such as Halo (just what came to mind when I was playing) and a world to explore.

I honestly didn’t know what to expect when I first hit play on this, but this wasn’t it.

There is a narrative here, that you discover in pieces. You can’t possibly do it all at once. There isn’t enough time.
Even knowing that there isn’t enough time though doesn’t stop you from pushing forwards. You can feel time running out as you go to the next location, needing to hear more about this world.

And much like our own world, we’re looking at it as it was, trying to avoid what is to come. I like to think that when I played this, I was able to get a story of my own. That there is no clear narrative to this game outside of the pre-determined factors that are known. Your role, can be as trivial, or as important as you can imagine it to be.

It’s not often that a world so small, can feel so massive. This world, frozen into a trickle of time, flames slowly licking the air, flowers slowly spinning in the air and water falling slowly. It tells a story of The Nomad, which for sake of the story itself I won’t tell anything about. The first time I played, I didn’t know what would happen. Then there was a moment of realization. It takes you on a journey through this world, but you’re in control of how you get there.

I found myself often exploring just to get another screenshot, one more picture for the library. There is a dream-like quality to the game, and it’s a great dream to have because of the beauty. It’s not about the end, but how you get to that point.

This can be  a small, short game, or it can last you days. How much time you want to put forth is your decision.  Is this a game I would recommend, yes. If only to support these artists in their work, and to have something, an experience to show your friends when they come over, because after having finished this game, that’s what it was. An Experience.

I've never been so delighted by a game before. I was expecting a walking simulator based around the concept of exploring a forgotten world. But there's this mechanic that gets introduced, and I don't want to spoil it, but the emotions that is conveyed when it first happen were so vivid and real- it was amazing. It's an exploration game with, and in all my years of gaming, has one of the most endearing and interesting mechanics with beauty in its simplicity. I've already said too much, please, go play it.


SPOILER

The idea is Impermanence. It flips the whole walking simulator / exploration genre on its head. I fully expected to explore the world looking for hidden secrets. In fact, I was kind of upset at the inclusion of this abstract map because I thought it hindered exploration. But as I neared the first landmark a twang of an acoustic guitar picked up and a subtle pacing began. I explored the landmark, checked out the plants growing, and was scaling up this hill when I was admiring this unique mosaic-esque art style the game has. Then I looked up and saw IT. A giant meteor seemingly breaking through the world leaving shattered pieces of the sky trailing behind it. I stood in marvel as it came closer and closer. I felt completely helpless and isolated, but endlessly intrigued. And then the screen faded to white...only to reapear at the beginning of the game.

You see, here's the catch: you're expected to explore as much as you can of this world within a ten minute limute (or 10 seconds slowed down as the description says). That's why you have the inclusion of the map. Each cycle" (as you later discover) has you frantically searching the different landmarks. And it creates this atmosphere of beautiful impermanence. Review Written on Sunday, May 15th, 2016

Review
TIMEframe is an atmospheric walking simulator telling a very gentle story. You aren't really told anything when you start and you have no clue as to what to do or where to go.

Once you start exploring the planet you soon begin to realise that the game involves walking around the landscape and investigating the various buildings, statues and points of interest. Every time you reach a new landmark you will get an achievement. There are 14 places of interest to visit and you don't have to pay admission to get into any of them. Each time a place is visited a very short story is told via text which gradually unravels the storyline.

I would recommend this game but it is easily completed to 100% in 2 hours and there isn't much to do apart from walk around and look at interesting objects and buildings. What makes this game enjoyable is the atmosphere and music in my opinion. The story is a bit minimal but the whole game shrieks minimal and sometimes its nice to be entertained for a couple of hours rather than wade through a 145 hour game. If you like walking simulators and enjoy a quick, relaxed and atmospheric game then I would buy this on sale.

reviewText:
Note: Yes, I finished the game. Also, this essay is a critique, not a review. Please note that I gave the game a positive review!

Games are so far not a great narrative medium.

There are, however, great examples of narrative/poetic work in games. Dear Esther, e.g., offers insight into the depths of game symbolism, while Gone Home points at the potential for environmental storytelling — yet it’s important to recognize that these approaches are only in their infancy. We don’t understand them very well, although we’re learning. Other examples of narrative cultivation can be found in games like Her Story, Braid, and Portal — and you can see intimations of success in games like TIMEframe.

To choose just one: Her Story is perhaps best characterized as a game unto itself, an experience carved into a new region of the gamespace. It pushes the boundaries of gaming in a new direction, from its complicated fracturing of narrative, to its (almost) unfamiliar use of the “unreliable narrator” — Her Story is a deep game, made with big intentions. As an indie gamer, this is an exciting time. Successful videogames are starting to try the models of mainstream entertainment and push the medium toward something more colorful and honest. Like photography grappling with Shore’s oeuvre, the games industry is beginning to look more alive.

So how does TIMEframe figure into this narrative? Well — it doesn’t. Not really. TIMEframe feels more like an ersatz copy of Dear Esther and less like the result of deep work.

Don’t get me wrong: — Aesthetically, TIMEframe is striking. Its polygonal style recalls old classics like Super Mario 64 and Final Fantasy VII (though the effect, I think, results more from texturing); its soundtrack plucks and soars at the right times, and not with undue majesty; and the environments one finds are, intermittently, fascinating (a town lies in a valley, its banners moving coldly, or there’s a statue of a man facing disaster with unerring courage). But these details unfold and merge with the same meandering that punctuates the work, and by the time the whole thing comes together, you feel — not edified — but cheated: Where is the substance? What am I supposed to take from this?

One big problem is that TIMEframe’s universe feels neither lived-in or abandoned. What might have been a sprawling, gorgeous empire presents, instead, as a desert — and a mostly hilly one at that. What buildings there are, scattered miles apart, feel isolated, inhuman, unlivable. In the game’s only town, there are no doors, no exits. Signs of shops and playgrounds of any sort have been scrubbed, and the way certain buildings merge with the earth is outright distracting. While some of these elements might be acceptable, it’s the confluence of them that lends TIMEframe its dream-like unreality. Be honest: What civilization would build itself this way?

[It’s also worth noting that TIMEframe positions you, the player, as the last observer of this doomed civilization — but the substance of the narrative does not flesh out this civilization, its culture, or the people who lived there. You learn one thing from something like 14 different pieces of text: Whoever these people were, however they lived, they were obsessed with death (and the impending meteor). So you have to ask yourself: “Why should I care?” Nothing here feels believable or grounded. Instead, TIMEframe favors a mediocrely-wrought philosophical romp to real narrative and believability. And that’s unfortunate.]

The end result of TIMEframe’s frequently unthoughtful design is not miserable or in any way worse than decent. In fact, TIMEframe is pleasant in the way of summer days in the park. But that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t be critical. If constant walking, a dearth of game mechanics, and a paucity of real substance and information feels like weakness, we should say that — and I’m going to say that: TIMEframe is, quite simply, too simple. It glances toward complication and deeper meaning but falls far short of that target — and the resulting game, while pleasant, is indicative of greater, more unique and powerful experiences. TIMEframe is simply a reminder of games which did it better . . .

But that doesn’t mean it’s not important; because TIMEframe marks the beginning of a trend toward deeper work in videogames. Yes, Her Story, Braid, Portal, Dear Esther, etc. did it better, and those games are better games (Note: They took much longer to make), but they feel too individual and scattered to summarize the indie market. With TIMEframe, and conscientious games like it, we as indie gamers are finally seeing the effect of these powerful, towering works and the influence they can have on the gaming industry. TIMEframe is in no way the beacon it was intended to be, but as a rallying force for better, truer experiences, you couldn’t ask for kinder encouragement.

reviewText:
Decent enough walking simulator; explore a valley about to be hit by a meteor in super slow motion.  I think it could have been much better if the meteor actually impacted, rather than the entire area fading to white when it was still a good thirty seconds away from the ground.  Terrain deformation and shrapnel would add a lot; although there are a lot of mysteriously broken things scattered around, falling in slow mo.  It could be that this is meant to represent an air burst; if so it would've been nice to see shrapnel from the meteor flying everywhere rather than the aforementioned white screen.

It also would be better if I could figure out a run button, or if the interesting sites in this place were less far apart.  And possibly more numerous.  Though I do like the texts that are scattered here and there.  Opening the main menu also does not pause the game, so there's no way to halt the meteor for a minute while you answer the phone or the door.  The timer is strict, and about ten minutes long.

It feels like someone's first game, and that's alright.  Buy if you want to support a game maker.

This was a nice, thoughtful game that some might consider relaxing, but I didn't I enjoyed it once I figured out what was going on, but I have a few nitpicks that I would like to see changed, even if I never touch this game again (it doesn't have much replayability).
1. I'm not playing on a high end computer, so I lowered the graphics settings so that it would run smoother. Every time the 10 minutes reset, so did the graphics settings. All the other game options stayed, but the graphics reset to the highest settings every time.
2. There's controller support, which is a plus, but even with the look sensitivity all the way up, looking around is slower with a controller than a mouse at half sensitivity.
3. You have to visit 14 different locations to finish the game. Every 10 minutes the game resets the setting and your position (but not your progress). This makes sense given the setting of the world, but you move so slowly that I was never able to visit more than 4 locations in one 10-minute cycle. And the world is so big compared to your walking speed, it feels like you're spending most of the time walking in a straight line towards your next location. It's about 3 minutes of holding W (or forwards on a controller). Very boring.
4. There is no way to pause the game and read the artifacts you find. When you find them, their text pops up, but the world keeps (slowly) going. When you open the menu (where you can read the artifacts as well as change game settings), the world keeps going. And once you beat the game, your progress is automatically reset so you can't take your time and read them then either.

All that said, it was a nice game and I would definitely recommend people play it once, if they can get it cheap. It's pretty much a one-and-done game.

Reading the other reviews for this game I see huge walls of text expounding upon the philosophy of the game and the deep thoughts it provokes. I'm not really going to do that here because honestly, I can't see myself spending more time writing about it than I did playing it. Plus I'm not that deep of a thinker.

It's a very pretty game, very stylized with a sort of triangular texture applied to everything. The soundtrack is simple but effective, becoming more elaborate with every new discovery. Basically, you're wandering through a landscape looking for various locations that will present you with a bit of text or information about the inhabitants that once lived in this area. By visiting all these areas you unlock the one last location on your map that implies where everybody went to escape the giant meteor that's getting ready to obliterate the world.

Yeah, that meteor. I hate that damned thing. After a few minutes you see it in the sky, getting closer every minutes until ten minutes have elapsed and the screen whites out, starting you back at the big tower in the center where you started. Thankfully your map still shows the locations you've visited so you can continue on your merry way, so it's not that huge of an obstacle. The reason I hate the meteor is because it turns a game that could be a relaxing contemplative exploration into a race against time to find the next location before you have to start over.

This game was very unique. But unfortunately, the main function of the game seems to be the thing that was wrong with it. The theme and atmosphere in the game was fantastic, and I really enjoyed this. I also really enjoyed uncovering a lost society and I think the artifacts and written passages were very well done. I cant say I hated it though because the atmosphere and music were terrific, but I just cant give it a thumbs up. Its really dissapointing that this game wasnt better because it had a lot of potential to be very good.
